Award.AwardTitle: Using Foraminiferal Nd Isotope Records to Test the Paradigm for Deglacial Atlantic Deepwater Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
Deepwater export from the northern North Atlantic to the ocean interior is widely believed to have decreased significantly during cold events of the last deglaciation (Heinrich Event 1 and the Younger Dryas). Motivated by recent debate on the topic, the proposed work will produce a novel reconstruction of Atlantic deglacial circulation based on well-dated records of neodymium isotope composition spanning the last ~25,000 years. These records will be developed from analyses of planktonic foraminifera from three depth transects in the western Atlantic (north, tropical, south). In combination with benthic oxygen and carbon isotope measurements, the neodymium isotope records will be used to 1) constrain potential end-member changes, 2) determine water mass variability in the upper, mid-depth, and deep Atlantic, and 3) evaluate the current paradigm of deglacial deepwater variability.

This work will advance the understanding of ocean circulation dynamics related to abrupt climate change. The project will support cross-disciplinary collaboration between a senior scientist and an early-career investigator at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution. Undergraduate and high school students will be trained in laboratory techniques. In addition, ten high school students from diverse backgrounds will be engaged through a one-week internship facilitated by the PI in collaboration with a local high school teacher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of our proposal was to use neodymium isotopes in depth transects of cores from the north, tropical, and south Atlantic to constrain glacial and deglacial circulation changes. Pairing these new records with benthic carbon isotope records from the same cores provided new insight into both glacial and deglacial circulation and carbon storage. It is generally believed that the fraction of waters sourced from the North Atlantic decreased during abrupt events of the last deglaciation, in response to a reduction in sinking of surface waters in the North Atlantic. By contrast our results suggest very little changs in the relative proportion of North and South Atlantic sourced waters, implying that the fraction of Southern Ocean waters entering the interior of the Atlantic also decreased during these events. Therefore, the benthic carbon isotope decreases observed during these events were the result of enhanced remineralization of organic carbon. Our results also suggest that while the proportion of southern source waters in the South Atlantic did not increase during these cold events, there were profound differences in water mass configuration in the tropical Atlantic. All these results are important for validating global climate models, and efforts are underway to collaborate on including these findings in data-model comaprisons. Funding provided support for two post-doctoral scientists.
